awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The effects of non-rainfall moisture inputs on dryland ecosystem functions
awd_abstract_narration:
Drylands, broadly defined as areas where mean annual precipitation is less than two-thirds of evaporative demand, account for nearly 40% of the global land surface and represent the largest terrestrial biome on the planet. Globally, ~2.5 billion people reside in drylands, and therefore drylands are socioeconomically important. The effect of non-rainfall precipitation components (e.g., fog and dew) on dryland ecosystems is one of the least studied aspects in hydrology. Quantifying and identifying the various sources of non-rainfall moisture to dryland systems are integral to predict how non-rainfall components will change under future climate change and how dryland ecosystems will respond accordingly. Through the use of emerging technology, comprehensive field observations and process-based modeling, this project will provide a key step toward understanding the origins and effects of non-rainfall inputs in dryland ecosystems. This project will include broad community outreach, and educate students at all levels (K-12, undergraduate and graduate), including those underrepresented in the STEM fields. These outreach and educational activities include education module development for third through ninth grade students, authentic research experiences for high school students, a summer teacher-training program for high school teachers, research abroad experience for undergraduate students, and professional development for graduate students. 
	
Despite the importance of non-rainfall precipitation, it remains unclear as to the amount of non-rainfall input that is needed to sustain dryland ecosystems. Furthermore the specific sources of non-rainfall water (e.g., ocean water vs. local groundwater), and the relative contribution of fog and dew, are not known for dryland systems. Quantifying and identifying the various sources of non-rainfall moisture to dryland systems are integral to predict how non-rainfall components will change under future climate change and how dryland ecosystems will respond accordingly. The overarching goal of this proposed research is to evaluate the effects of non-rainfall inputs on dryland ecosystem functions through stable isotope (2H, 17O and 18O) and modeling analyses. The field research will be conducted at a long-standing international station in Namibia (Gobabeb Research and Training Center) due to its unique ecological location, prior research and existing logistics for conducting field research at the proposed site.

por.por_cntn:
Globally, drylands account for over 40% of the earth’s terrestrial surface and are characterized by low rainfall resulting in permanent or seasonal water deficit. As water is a limiting resource in drylands, precipitation undoubtedly plays an essential role in determining the composition of dryland vegetation and soil biogeochemical dynamics. There is accumulating evidence from multiple continents that the small but critical amount of fog and dew input into dryland systems is important for ecosystem functions. Despite this, it is unclear to what extent these non-rainfall water sources contribute to ecosystem functions, what are the specific sources (e.g., ocean water vs. local groundwater) of these fog/dew waters in dryland systems and what is the relative contribution of fog and dew. Quantifying the amount and identifying the sources of non-rainfall moisture inputs is integral to projecting how non-rainfall components will change under a future climate and predicting how dryland ecosystems will respond to the projected changes in non-rainfall components. The overarching goal of this project is to evaluate the effects of non-rainfall inputs on dryland ecosystem functions through stable isotopes and modeling analyses. This study was conducted at a long-standing international station in Namibia (Gobabeb Namib Research Institute) due to its unique ecological location, prior research, and existing logistics.

For the first time, our findings revealed that both fog and dew have multiple moisture origins, and groundwater in the desert played an important role in moisture provision through evapotranspiration. For the first time, we used the δ17O-δ18O relationship to distinguish fog from dew, as their formation is governed by equilibrium and kinetic fractionation processes, respectively. We also used the δ17O-δ18O relationship to identify dew evaporation during formation under different climate conditions. We found the intense global warming of the past decade has shifted the impact of global warming on fog from positive to negative, reducing fog availability. Additionally, we observed that El Niño events have increased fog variability since 2012. Both the decreasing fog availability and increasing fog variability pose significant challenges to the resilience of organisms in fog-dependent ecosystems. This project also provided the first comprehensive assessment of the effects of non-rainfall waters on soil water potentials and plant water status within the Namib Desert. We developed a modeling framework to simulate fog impact on soil moisture dynamics. Our findings indicate that the positive impacts of fog on vegetation can be quantitatively evaluated via remote sensing, paving the way for fog-vegetation interaction research at large spatial scales. We found that fog plays a more significant role than rainfall in explaining vegetation greenness change rates, while accumulated rainfall has a stronger influence than fog in determining overall vegetation greenness.

The project produced 73 peer-reviewed journal articles and generated 50 presentations at national and international conferences. Six field trips to Namibia were conducted during the funding period, with over 2,500 non-rainfall water samples collected from the study area. Two undergraduate interns participated in our field trips to Namibia in 2017 and 2022. The project also provided training and laboratory experiences for two postdoc researchers, four Ph.D. students, four M.S. students, 14 undergraduate students, and eight high school students. During field trips to Namibia, we hosted informal seminars to demonstrate instrument principles and operations and to explain isotope techniques to local researchers. In 2017, the PI participated in a Biophysical Field Methods training hosted by Gobabeb. Additionally, the project offered a week-long summer training workshop to local high school teachers on the impacts of climate change on hydrological cycles at the Indian University Indianapolis (IUI) campus in the summers of 2018 and 2019. We also worked with a firm to create a free online resource based on the project findings aimed at encouraging 14-19-year-olds worldwide to pursue careers in science. The PI's lab hosted minority high school students for one or two months each summer from 2016 to 2020 through the Indianapolis Project SEED (Summer Experience for the Economically Disadvantaged) program, with each student presenting their research results at the Project SEED Symposium at the end of the summer. In collaboration with the IUI Center for Earth and Environmental Science, the PI developed a one-hour-long education module entitled “Water availability in arid regions” for 4th to 12th-grade students in 2018. The PI’s group also participated in the 5th through 8th Young Innovators Quest summer programs from 2016 to 2019, giving presentations and hosting lab tours. From 2016 to 2023, the PI organized 22 sessions at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall meeting. The PI also presented three first-authored education posters at the AGU Fall Meeting in 2018, 2020, and 2021, and delivered a first-authored education talk at the AGU Fall Meeting in 2022. In 2023, the PI published a first-authored peer-reviewed article in the Journal of Geoscience Education, reflecting on experiences working with high school students in virtual environments during the COVID-19 period.
